docs.lead_paragraph: The health care law will affect not only who gets into the examining room, but also what goes on there.

headline.seo: Health Care Mandate Puts a Cranky Uncle in Every Exam Room
headline.main: Cranky Uncles, for Better or Worse, Will Lurk in More Exam Rooms
headline.print_headline: Cranky Uncles, for Better or Worse, Will Lurk in More Exam Rooms

docs.abstract: Dr Abigail Zuger essay compares the health coverage provided under the upheld individual health insurance mandate to a rich uncle with deep pockets but a volatile personality, who sometimes helps, but just as often hinders patient care.
docs.snippet: The health care law will affect not only who gets into the examining room, but also what goes on there.

docs.lead_paragraph: BARTLETT--Peter Barry. February 21, 1934 -- June 27, 2012. Peter Barry Bartlett passed away peacefully in his home in New York City on June 27, 2012. He was born in Boulder, Colorado in 1934 an only child to Christopher Hammond Bartlett and Marie Powers Bartlett. He graduated from Phillips Andover Academy in 1952 as a varsity basketball and soccer player. He then graduated from Yale University in 1956 where he was the Captain of the 1955 soccer team. As goalie, he held the career shutout record for over 30 years. Upon graduating, he moved to New York City and joined Brown Brothers Harriman, Inc. where he was named Partner in 1974. He served on the Steering Committee for 15 years and was the supervising partner of Banking and Treasury. Peter remained a Limited Partner until his death. He was a 30-year member of the Board of Directors for Kennametal Inc. and also a board member for Erie Insurance. He served his community as a member of the Board of Directors for Beekman Downtown Hospital and as a member of the Pension and Investment Subcommittee at Meridian Health System, Inc. An avid outdoorsman and sports enthusiast, he raised his family in Summit, NJ and in later years divided his time between his homes in Bay Head, NJ and Kiawah, SC. He served on the Finance Committee at the Bay head Yacht Club and was a founding member of Briar's Creek Golf Club on St. John's Island, SC. He also enjoyed spending time at The Links Club in New York and Rolling Rock Hunt Pony Club in Ligonier, PA. As a devoted family man and friend, he will be missed by all who knew him. He is survived by his former wife Elizabeth Easton Bartlett of NY, NY and Weston, CT and his children, Kim Kernan, of Rowayton, CT, Chris Bartlett of New Canaan, CT and Gibson Island, MD, Kate Lieder of Ridgefield, CT and Ian Duvenhage of Nashville, TN. He is also survived by his six grandchildren, Peter and Avery Kernan, Elizabeth and Nicholas Bartlett and Christopher and Carly Lieder. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to New York Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children 161 William Street, 9th Floor, NY, NY 10038 or The Boy's Club of New York 287 East 10th Street, NY, NY 10009. Information regarding a Memorial Service will be announced at a later date.

headline.main: Romney Campaign at Odds With G.O.P. on Health Care 'Tax'

docs.abstract: Republicans are trying hard to accuse President Obama of increasing taxes on middle class Americans in the wake of the Supreme Court’s ruling on health care. But they are doing so without the help of Mitt Romney.
docs.snippet: Republicans are trying hard to accuse President Obama of increasing taxes on middle class Americans in the wake of the Supreme Court’s ruling on health care. But they are doing so without the help of Mitt Romney.

docs.lead_paragraph: Since President Obama swept into office with vast backing from young people, a new corps of voters have come of age with views shaped by the recession.

headline.seo: Economy Cuts Into Obama’s Youth Support
headline.main: Stung by Recession, Young Voters Shed Image as Obama Brigade
headline.print_headline: Stung by Recession, Young Voters Shed Image as Obama Brigade

docs.abstract: Nation's first-time voters, unlike their counterparts in the millennial generation who showed high levels of enthusiasm for Mr. Obama, are less enthusiastic about him and significantly more likely to identify as themselves as conservative; their views are shaped largely by the recession and many cite a growing lack of faith in government in general.
docs.snippet: Since President Obama swept into office with vast backing from young people, a new corps of voters have come of age with views shaped by the recession.

byline.contributor: Robbie Brown contributed reporting from Atlanta, and Malia Wollan from San Francisco. Kitty Bennett contributed research.

headline.main: Obama Aide Rejects 'Tax' Label for Health Care Law

docs.abstract: The White House chief of staff, in interviews, defended President Obama's health care law but rejected the "tax" label that the Supreme Court, in a ruling last week that mostly upheld the law, used to describe the penalty payment required for those who choose to not buy health insurance.
